title: Tradition and Faith
shortSummary: Matthew 15 addresses the conflict between Jesus and the Pharisees over religious traditions versus God's commandments, emphasizing the importance of inner purity over external rituals. The chapter also highlights Jesus' compassion through the healing of many and the miraculous feeding of the four thousand, demonstrating His divine authority and care.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Ministry of Jesus in Galilee and surrounding regions

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Messiah and Son of David who teaches about true purity, confronts religious hypocrisy, heals the sick, and performs miracles.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders from Jerusalem who challenge Jesus about His disciples not following traditional hand-washing customs.

keyCharacters.name: Disciples
keyCharacters.description: Followers of Jesus who learn from His teachings and witness His miracles, including Peter who asks for clarification on Jesus' parables.

keyCharacters.name: Canaanite Woman
keyCharacters.description: A Gentile woman demonstrating great faith by persistently seeking Jesus’ help for her demon-possessed daughter.

definitions.definition: Oral laws and customs developed by Jewish religious leaders that were added to God's commandments but sometimes conflicted with Scripture.
A Jewish sect known for strict adherence to the law and traditions, often criticized by Jesus for hypocrisy.
To make unclean or impure, especially in a moral or spiritual sense.

definitions.term: Lost sheep of the house of Israel
definitions.definition: A metaphor referring to the Jewish people who were spiritually lost and in need of salvation.
A term used by Jews to refer to Gentiles, often derogatory but here used in a dialogue to highlight faith beyond ethnic boundaries.

outline.heading: Jesus Confronts Pharisees on Tradition
outline.description: Jesus challenges the Pharisees for prioritizing human traditions over God's commandments, teaching that true defilement comes from the heart, not external rituals like hand washing.

outline.heading: Faith of the Canaanite Woman
outline.description: A Gentile woman persistently seeks Jesus' mercy for her daughter, and Jesus commends her great faith, resulting in her daughter's healing, illustrating the extension of God's grace beyond Israel.

outline.heading: Jesus Heals and Feeds the Multitude
outline.description: Jesus heals many who are sick and disabled and miraculously feeds four thousand men plus women and children, demonstrating His compassion and divine provision.

application: Evaluate your heart’s motives and prioritize obedience to God’s Word over man-made traditions or rituals.
Approach Jesus with persistent faith, trusting in His mercy and power regardless of your background or circumstances.
Show compassion to those in need, following Jesus’ example of caring for the sick and hungry.
Trust in God’s provision even when resources seem insufficient, remembering His ability to multiply and provide abundantly.

keyVerses.text: Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Jesus’ teaching that true spiritual defilement comes from the heart, not external observances.

keyVerses.text: Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith: be it unto thee even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the power of faith and Jesus’ willingness to extend grace to those outside Israel.

keyVerses.text: Then Jesus called his disciples unto him, and said, I have compassion on the multitude, because they continue with me now three days, and have nothing to eat: and I will not send them away fasting, lest they faint in the way.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ compassion and concern for both spiritual and physical needs.
